docs.lead_paragraph: David Greer, a doctor who co-founded a group that won the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize for working to prevent nuclear war and who helped transform the medical school at Brown University, has died. He was 89.

headline.main: Former Brown Dean Whose Group Won Nobel Prize Dies
headline.print_headline: Former Brown Dean Whose Group Won Nobel Prize Dies

docs.snippet: David Greer, a doctor who co-founded a group that won the 1985 Nobel Peace Prize for working to prevent nuclear war and who helped transform the medical school at Brown University, has died. He was 89.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama said Thursday that 19 scientists, researchers and innovators who received the country's highest honor for their life-changing work embody the spirit of the nation and its "sense that we push against limits and that we're not afraid to ask questions."

headline.main: Obama Plugs Science, Math Education at Ceremony

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers are optimistic about recent efforts to delay the effects of aging and, perhaps, extend life spans.

headline.main: Science (and Quacks) vs. the Aging Process
headline.print_headline: Science (and Quacks) vs. the Aging Process

docs.abstract: Scientific community is optimistic about efforts to improve longevity, but warns against spending money on products that offer fantastic claims; researchers say, while they are not able to stop or reverse aging, they can slow rate at which people get old and keep people healthier longer.
docs.snippet: Researchers are optimistic about recent efforts to delay the effects of aging and, perhaps, extend life spans.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many people over age 65 lack dental insurance, a benefit that isn’t covered by traditional Medicare, and those eligible for Medicaid have limited coverage, depending on where they live.
docs.abstract: Older Americans face problem of paying out of pocket for dental care since many people over 65 lack dental insurance; federal Medicare program does not cover routine dental care or dentures, and many Medicare managed care plans offer limited coverage.
docs.snippet: Many people over age 65 lack dental insurance, a benefit that isn’t covered by traditional Medicare, and those eligible for Medicaid have limited coverage, depending on where they live.

docs.lead_paragraph: ABRAMS--Jerome, MD, died peacefully after a distinguished career in Obstetrics and Gynecology in the Plainfields and Fanwood, NJ. Born in Plainfield to Leah Cantor Abrams and Hyman Abrams, he served as an Ensign in the Pacific during WWII. After graduating from Swarthmore, he obtained an MA in History from Columbia University and completed his MD and residency at Jefferson. He published numerous articles in the field of Ob-Gyn, was an associate editor of the New Jersey Medical Journal, and a Clinical Professor at Rutgers Medical School. Later in his career he obtained a Masters of Public Health from Rutgers University. Passionate about opera and history, in the early 1960's he was published in the Metropolitan Opera News. After retirement he was a frequent lecturer at Rutgers Institute for Lifelong Learning in the fields of History, Political Science and Medicine. A gentleman, scholar, and renaissance man, he was kind and loving to his wife Rosalyn Yaskin, his sons Alan (Cheryl) of Villanova, PA, Joseph (Marie) of Rye, NY, his grandchildren Harrison, Emilie, Thomas, and Jonathan, and his brother Hon. Herbert Abrams (Joan) of Brookline MA. Donations in his name to the Center for Hope Hospice of Scotch Plains, NJ or the Parkinson's Disease Foundation would be appreciated. 1/3

docs.lead_paragraph: Our high-tech process of pharmaceutical research is broken — and the solution might be old-fashioned trial and error.

headline.main: Why Are So Few Blockbuster Drugs Invented Today?

docs.abstract: Most drug companies have continued to devote vast majority of their funding to target-based research, informed by genomics, despite fact that more traditional methods of drug discovery like trial-and-error have proved more productive; example of trial-and-error method yielding positive result is research that chemical engineer Todd Zion has done on developing better form of insulin, promise of which has led Merck to acquire Zion's company SmartCells.
docs.snippet: Our high-tech process of pharmaceutical research is broken — and the solution might be old-fashioned trial and error.
